For example, in the video example the id of the video was long (do not remember the exact phrase), however, in the example for the module the id of the video was changed to just video and not the id from the previous examples, whereas other ids were kept as in their examples. So, this is a bit confusing.

The questions order in the generated module preview is different to the one that was entered in the code. It would be nice to be able to check if the assignment of wrong and correct works. Not sure if that was possible.

In general, I have a good impression. The availability of the accelerators in terms of suggested code words is a great time saver.

comments.CNL:
Positive notes:
+ the documentation is easy to understand
+ documentation stays open while typing
Negative notes:
- cannot copy/paste from the docs
- if I click a timestamp in the preview it jumps to the video (on the same tab)
- not all commands are intuitive, e.g., why is "with" used only with "id", except for the module? Can I use "with" also with, e.g. "URL"? 
- why is upper case mandatory?
comments.KV:
Positive notes:
+ the notation is very clear, no inconsistencies
+ easier to learn

Negative
- not human readable
- notation might need background information/experience in programming
RANKINGEXPLAIN: - easier to learn the syntax, less syntactical details
GENERALCOMMENTS:
The answers here are subjective, i.e., I personally have experience with programming and markup languages, etc.

If you ask me, if the textual notation would be useful for non-experienced, non-technical people my answers would be different. I would clearly say that the combination of a editing GUI and a simple notation language could be helpful to these people.

comments.CNL: Very convenient language, easy to use
comments.KV: Very concise, but also convenient and easy to use
RANKINGEXPLAIN: Both are easy to use, key-value notation is more concise and probably therefore for longer videos more convenient

comments.CNL:
Some code lines appear a bit long... this can be cumbersome in daily use. There are lot of repetitions needed; maybe an additional auto-completion (or suggestions/recommendations) would help.
I like the autocompletion suggestions. Also the examples help.
comments.KV:
easy to use.
reminds me a bit of the syntax for markdown as used in hugo (for websites)

i like that it is quite short

auto-complete for syntax would be useful. e.g., for instance if a line starts with "video", then there are several options for attributes such as "title" or "URL" - these could be suggested.
RANKINGEXPLAIN:
the key-value notation is far shorter. making it more concise.
the N-L notation is long. and it is easy to forget a part. first create, then set,... etc. it makes it lengthy, which is unnecessary complex (to read the code afterwards; also to find an error)

comments.CNL:
This natural language notation was more intuitive to use and therefore is faster. I finished "successfully" within 22 minutes, because I was stuck on an error for 15 minutes. The error feedback ("extra characters after close-quote") wasn't helpful, as it didn't tell me what line this was on and actually mislead me to looking for the error in the wrong places. 

The actual mistake I made was I used the wrong syntax for the answers of the question. I used a notation similar to that of the first experiment: "Set answer of q1 to ("Answer 1", correct "Answer 2", wrong) instead of: "Set answer of q1 to "Answer 1" which is correct, Set answer of q1 to "Answer 2" which is false". This was simply a mistake on my part and not due to a flaw of the natural language notation. I believe that now I would be more confident and also faster using this notation over the previous one!
comments.KV:
The information windows that pops when clicking the buttons (e.g. "Video", "Question") covers a part of the code and the window isn't moveable. It would be nice to be able to drag the window.

It would also be nice if the identifiers (e.g. "URL", "title") were colored, just to give the user a confirmation.

Other than that, it was really easy to navigate the tool and everything was clear. I finished successfully and I didn't find it difficult. My first general impression however is that it might be nice to have some interactive elements, for example: drag a box titled "video" into the storyboard editing field (bottom left box) which will automatically insert the code. It will then prompt you to insert a title, if you want timestamps, etc. This might be more intuitive and faster than writing code.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: As stated previously, i find the natural-language notation to be more intuitive and therefore faster to use.
GENERALCOMMENTS: I feel like the combination of a GUI and textual notation is the best. The GUI would be good for creating the main structure of the module (what goes where, how big should the textfield or embedded video be, etc). And the textual notation would be good for further refinements (e.g. creating the question/answer form, setting title of elements, etc). You should be able to switch between GUI and textual notation in my opinion!

RANKINGEXPLAIN: The Key-Value notation is more consistent in the way that you do not need to choose between add/set/create for every action, it is more straight forward. The simplicity saves time and the code looks better(is easier to read).

comments.CNL: I found this natural language notation more cumbersome than the first one. It seemed less consistent, I felt that I had to use unnecessary adverbs, it was more spurious and not as easy to remember. RANKINGEXPLAIN: Both key-value notation and natural-language notation are easy enough, but the key-value notation is more consistent and easier to memorize (at least to me). I have limited programming experience, but I do program my lecture slides in Latex, as I find this far more easier than drag-and-drop in PowerPoint.
GENERALCOMMENTS:
I find video editing (in Linux with KdenLive) quite cumbersome and find it hard to work with the graphical timeline. For me, a programming approach would work much better. Also, I could more easily scroll back to check whether I defined all the timepoints and other things that I wanted to define (it gives me a better overview).

In terms of logic, it struck me as odd that I was allowed to already add material to the video before I defined them. In programming, using or referring to variables before you defined them, is strongly discouraged. I also think that for humans it is more logical to first define/create all items and then integrate them.

comments.CNL:
interesting experience, quite easy to understand. What confused me at first is that functions (Create, Set, Add) are case-sensitive, but "types" like video, timestamp etc. are not, even though they start with large letters in the help box. 
However, as programmers are usually lazy and to avoid irrelevant errors when compiling, I would prefer as less case-sensitive commands as possible.
comments.KV: it was also quite easy and understandable. For such a simple task it is more efficient and consistent to write, but not that easy to read and understand. In once case there is a unnecessary ambiguity: <question "id_question" question "this is the question"> shows that it is not as clear as <Set question "id_question" to "this is the question">
RANKINGEXPLAIN:
It feels more natural, easy to understand even after not looking at it for several hours/days/weeks.
If the code is longer than just a few rows (eg for a website with multiple videos -> learning path), the natural language helps for better understanding and debugging the code as it is easy to understand when an object gets declared or a an attribute set. In comparison, the Key-Value Notation looks the same in the beginnng and one has to ready the full line to understand what is done with the object (timestamp, video...).
Furthermore, if one has experience with SQL, Python etc., it feels more logically as it reminds of object oriented programming (with classes and attributes).

comments.CNL: I finished successfully and the notation was actually really hopefully to find my errors otherwise I probably wouldn't have found the error on my own.
comments.KV: i finished successfully this time even faster. its really easy to use this notation once you get familiar with it
RANKINGEXPLAIN: I think the key-value is easier to use because there isn't so much text so you can have an better overview than with the other notation. its just that you are more likely to make mistakes with the natural -language than with the key value.

comments.CNL:
Although my answers may be biased as at this point I am implicitly comparing the "natural-language" notation with the key-value notation, in general my experience with the "natural-language" one is rather unpleasant. While the usage of "create" vs "set" commands at least makes sense, the sudden introduction of the "add" command is really confusing. Why does one "add" timestamps to the video but does not "add" answers to question, for example?
While this notation is more similar to imperative programming languages, where one actively "creates" objects and "sets" their properties, the attempt to make it sound more like a natural language with the excessive use of "with", "of", "which is", etc. makes the script so ridiculous that I would be more happy with something completely "technical" like v1.url="youtube.com/something" rathet than "Set URL of v1 to youtube.com/something".
comments.KV:
In general, I enjoyed the editing process very much. I think the syntax is very well-thought. However, I have a couple of suggestions:
1. In "video", the URL key is upper-case while all other keys are lower-case, why not just keep the url key lower-case as well? Also, it would be nice for consistency and probably security to enclose the URL value in parentheses in the same way as strings.
2. In "question", the word "question" is used both as a classname and as keyword, this might confuse some users. I would suggest changing the key name to "body" or something similar. Also, the structure of the answer key where text strings are interchanging with boolean wrong/correct values may lead to confusion and errors, I would suggest using some nested key-value structure there, e.g. question q1 answers (("Wrong answer", wrong), ("Correct answer", correct)). (Maybe there is an even better way to do it). While it would make the notation more complicated, it will be more structured, which will be beneficial to some users.
RANKINGEXPLAIN:
The key-value notation is a declarative one, and this is no surprise it is more convenient for creating static content like such learning modules, look back at HTML, which is also declarative and has been used successfully to structure web pages for the last 3 decades. It just feels natural.
The "natural-language" notation looks like an imperative programming language with an excessive amount of prepositions and rather weird word order, which in my opinion takes the worst from both worlds: imperative programming languages and natural languages. First, in contrast to the argument I had for the key-value notation, one would seldom use an imperative programming language to create content manually. It does makes sense to use it for automated content generation, e.g. you have a ready database with video URLs, course titles and texts and you want to automatically generate similar web pages for them, but for a case where every page is to some extent uniquely handcrafted it is just a massive overkill. Second, the attempt to make it sound more like natural language did not work out nicely in my opinion. While I clearly see the purpose behind it, which is to make the language more appealing to non-technical users, the excessive usage of prepositions like "of", "with", etc. just makes the text look clumsy. On top of that, the word order required to make it sound more natural, i.e. set attribute of id to value, just hurts a programmer's eye a bit.
GENERALCOMMENTS: The comparison of the two notations is yet another instance of the somewhat classical declarative vs imperative debate. Are there no existing studies on which one fits better for the purpose?

comments.CNL: I am not at all accustomed to use notations like this, but the video tutorial explained very well how to use it and the explanations and examples in the editing board itself were very helpful. Well, to be honest I just followed the instructions step by step and used the examples in the editing board menu to fulfill the task in an analogous manner. Without these examples I would not have been able to get started at all. So I wonder, how I would use the notation system to create anything that differs from what is explained and shown in the editing board...
comments.KV:
For the second task I needed half of the time compared to the first task. This is mainly due to the fact that I learned a lot from working on the first task.
I see that the key-value notation is also quicker to use because you need to type less text.
Nevertheless I find both notation formats equally easy or complex to use. In both cases I followed the instructions step by step and used the examples to complete the task in an analogous manner. It was not problem for me to do this. But in both cases my concern is, how I could use the notation system to create content that differns from what is shown in the examples...
RANKINGEXPLAIN:
As already commented, I find both notation formats more or less equally easy or complex to use. 
But the advantage of the key-value notation is, that you have to type less text, so you save time and it is less error-prone.
GENERALCOMMENTS:
For me it was the first time to use a notation system like this and I don´t have any experience with programming, so I am not very confident.
But I think if I used such a notation system more often and if it would be combined with a GUI representation, I could get accustomed to it. Especially if there are very easy step by step explanations with examples how to use the tool, like in this case.
In the end, I think it is a very interesting tool!

comments.CNL: I found it cumbersome to use this notation language, although I got used to it after a while. Again, step-by-step and I believe to have finished succesfully. I think, with so many commands, it gets unnecessarily complex.

After I checked what I have created, I have found minor mistakes like the structure of the module was wrong, but I believe that I finished successfully. I enjoyed programming with this language, although normally I don't like programming that much.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: The reason for the ranking is that I found the Key-Value notation easier to use. As there were more commands to type in in the natural language notation, I found it harder, even though I finished faster. But the faster pace was due to the fact that I got accustomed to the task, and I believe it was not due to the notation languages.

comments.KV: again this is easy to use, particularly after using the natural language notation. However, I prefer the natural language notation as using commands like "create", "set", and "add" is more straightforward, and I do not need to always check which part I'm working on. To be more precise, I can imagine that it would be easier for me to make mistakes when using key value as command as compared with natural language, especially if the tasks get more complicated.

both notations are easy to use, but personally it's easier to use commands like "create", "set", and "add", as it allows greater flexibility in my opinion. While working with the key-value notation, I always need to check which part I'm working on before entering the commands, which is not the case while using natural-language notation. As soon as I have the instruction flow by heart, I mostly know what to do with the natural-language notation as the script is more or less the same for all parts - "id", "title", "body". Also, since I'm a person with typo all the times, key-value notation may make it harder for me to find the typo.


this is just my personal feeling.

comments.CNL: I think that this notation has too much unnecessary wordings; overall I had the same approach like the first task
comments.KV: it was quite easy to do, given the documentation that was availble and the video tutorial

comments.CNL: The editor is easy to use. Even for a person who does not come from the field of computer science, it is very easy to understand the principles of the program. However, it would have been helpful, if the importance of the input (capital letters for example)  would have been emphasized the explanatory video. I had to correct some mistakes in the end. comments.KV: Its a lot easier compared to the first one - very simple, no unnecessary words. The experiment has shown me that just the commands (Create, Set,..) are very prone to errors
RANKINGEXPLAIN:
the Typing (Capital Letters) is important in the Natural-Language and therefore a source for errors. The Key-Value Notation is not as easy to understand as the Natural-Language (for a first user), because you do not see the commands.

I think it was helpful to use the Natural-Language Notation first, the transfer to the Key-Value was easy then. The Natural-Language Notation shows the structure better, the key-value Notation is more simplex and more easy to use though.
GENERALCOMMENTS: It is helpful to have a formula in an GUI (e.g. moodle) that helps with the usability but it is also very helpful (e.g. for e-developers) to see the coding behind in such an editor. It it often easier to change things in the Notation.

However, if the person wants to do something more complex than just adding questions and videos and have no prior coding experience I think it could be a bit difficult to use and technical support would be needed in that case.

It would be nice to have it in the 'help window' and just fill the necessary data, I think it would be much faster to create the modules, especially for people with no coding experience. Or at least to have a possibility to copy the code from the help window. Also, the autofill for some commands is not working which makes it prone to typos which I personally always struggle with. Anyway, this variant of the language was much clearer than the previous one.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: I think Key-Value is much clearer to use, the body of the code is not so crowdy.

comments.CNL:
Der Prozess war gut, ärgerlich und mühsam fand ich die Groß- und Kleinschreibung auf die man achten musste...
Habe es erfolgreich abgeschlossen und bin mit meinem Prozess und dem Ergebnis zufrieden.
Auch hier mit dem Hilfebereich gut lösbar
comments.KV:
Mit der Hilfestellung war die Aufgabe gut lösbar und ich war richtig angefuchst die Aufgabe fertigzustellen. Die Freude über das korrekte Ergebnis war groß.
Einzig bei der Frage war mir unklar, wie denn der Titel lauten soll, da es hier keine Übereinstimmung zwischen Aufgabe und Hilfe gab.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: Natural-Language Notation Ist leichter auf unterschiedliche Kontexte umzulegen und vom Aufbau her logischer (bis auf die Groß- und Kleinschreibung...)

comments.CNL: This was also very easy to use, however in this example we had more lines in the code. So, from that point of view the first task was a bit easier. Apart from that, everything was fine, I even mange to finish this one faster.
comments.KV: I think the notation was very easy to use. I am not very experienced in programming and it was really easy for me because of how everything was well explained. I just followed every step exactly as it was written in the instructions, and in the end, I managed to complete the task successfully.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: I prefere Key-value Notation because there is less text to type, and code is shorter in the end.
Using the Key-Value Notation saves a lot of time.

comments.CNL:
I found the following:
1. The instructions were quite cramped. If the steps would have been in a bullet point list, I might have been able to follow them better. One of the reasons for spending a few extra minutes on the task was due to having to jump between windows (instruction/documentation/script), which made me lose the trail of thought. 

2. The text editor is quite simple in its functionality. The auto-completion was present but limited. There was no apparent way of commenting on lines of code, and the error message was very basic.

3. The documentation pop-up window was obstructive. I tried different window sizes, yet the pop-up window was always on top of the text editor. This made it challenging to write as it was hiding part of the text.

4. I am unsure how this way of creating storyboards is better than a more drag-and-drop interface. I wished I could simply click on the buttons from the documentation section and instantly get the line of code corresponding to that command. 
The NLP part is only marginally improving the readability of the script, but it yet resembles a lot of a high-level interpreting language like Python. Writing letter by letter (a limitation of the text editor) makes it more cumbersome than useful.

5. I am curious to see how this tool will evolve. It seems to be at a beta stage, and many more established features from other IDEs could be implemented.
comments.KV:
The second round was easier as I simply got the gist of using the interface and hopping between documentation and instructions. However, I lost some precious time (;) joking) as I copy pasted a snippet of text at the end of the script that I did not see as the text editor does not allow full-screen preview mode. It took me some time to figure out where the error was as the error message did not indicate which line to look.

However, the second time was much more fun.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: Although the differences were subtle, I found the key-value notation way more succinct and intuitive.
GENERALCOMMENTS: I think the tool is at a promising start, and through cycles of iterations and incremental improvements in the UI, the IntelliSense, and the language, it could be useful in the near future.

comments.CNL: This notation is focused on actions instead of elements. It is also relatively easy to use, but not as easy as the first one.
comments.KV: Notation is well designed and easy to use. However some commands could be grouped together to avoid possible errors with wrong IDs (e.g. title + body).
RANKINGEXPLAIN: Both notations are easy to use, however I think that programming experiece is more important for the key-value notation. Therefore, with the first one a broader audience can be addressed.
GENERALCOMMENTS: I would prefer to start with a GUI for the first draft and to do a "fine tuning" with the textual notation.

comments.CNL: I finished writing everyting after about 10 minutes, but kept getting the feedback: can't read "prompt": no such variable. I was not able to see or find what the problem was based on the feedback, to i did submit it.
comments.KV: It all went well, I just forgot to add one line with the queastion about the type of question, which caused me to lose some time. I did not immediately notice that all lines of a certain commands had to be in there.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: I think if I had to work with the key-language in the second part of the experiment, I would have been able to complete it faster. It just works easier in comparison to the NLN. But also:  I was not able to complete the task with the NLN, but with the key-value notation I was (after finding my typing mistake)
GENERALCOMMENTS: It might be interesting if the feedback part in de script can highlight the 'mistake' in the writting language. This might make it easier to quickly find a mistake, but I also understand that this might not always be able (depending on the 'mistake')

RANKINGEXPLAIN:
Key-Value notation is faster to use, because it leaves away unaccesary words like to.
The reason I was faster in the second attempt was a learning effect.
Otherwise the natural-language notation would be slower.

comments.CNL:
It was ok. Due to the natural language constructs it was a little bit more difficult to remember how to write the statement. E.g. the "wich is" part of Questions.
I dont know the other commands available in this notation, but i would suggest to create a language with only few but consistent keywords (e.g. "which is" is also used in an "if" statement).
It was also more cumbersome, since i had to write more words.
comments.KV: I missed some sort of code-completion or keyword suggestion features like in many programming EDIs.
RANKINGEXPLAIN:
For me as a person with experience in C++ Programming, the simpler notation gets a higher rank. For me it is easier to use and to read. But thats due to my experience with programming languages.

However, i think the natural language version, like a higher programming language, could be more effective, when it comes to more complex and more modularized Systems. That is, if more keywords are added to the language, then you have standardized keywords like "create", you allready know and do not need to learn the syntax. In addition, when the system allows to add libraries or modules to integrate new functionality, then a collection of standardized keywords is necessary. Otherwise a library is always introducing new commands, which one needs to learn, making it unusable.

comments.CNL: Autocompletion was a drawback of this notion. This notation is very verbose, and not concise, which I do not like. This notation is far from real natural language which requires some sense of intelligence
comments.KV:
I disliked the redudancy in the representation, like writing "question q" over and over again; however, I acknowledge that this makes the system easier for beginners to use.

I would prefer a full gui over text + webforms.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: Both notations are verbose, but natural language is much more verbose and cumbersome to debug since it is so much more redundant text.
GENERALCOMMENTS: I would rather have only a GUI and nothing else.

comments.CNL: I found the task rather easy. There was one small mistake I made when submitting the task. The error did not tell me what exactly was the mistake, but it helped. Still, these error messages are way better than the ones you get when you are coding, so I am not complaining. I think I finished successfully and I had time to check what I did too. My process of approaching this task was the same as in the instruction video - I simply followed the steps one by one.
comments.KV: My approach was very similar to the previous task. However, I hope this time my solution is correct, since after watching the second video tutorial I realised that I made some mistakes. I had to pay more attention to the notation now, since I was already "used to" the previous notation, but that was not a problem.
RANKINGEXPLAIN: I could imagine working with both notations, since I believe they are quite straight-forward. However, if I had to choose, I would prefer the second (Key-Value Notation) just because it is shorter, still easy to comprehend, and one does not need to use so many "unnecessary" words.
Das könnte aber auch daran liegen, dass ich Key-Value Notation mit der generellen Struktur bereits vertrauter war.
GENERALCOMMENTS: Wenn man mit Programmiersprachen nicht vertraut ist bzw. diese länger nicht genutzt hat, stellt das für mich (trotz sehr guter Erklärungen) eine Einstiegshürde dar bzw. führt dazu, dass man evtl. mehr Zeit für die Umsetzung benötigt.
